message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest pulmonary hypertension, and the genetic analysis confirms the diagnosis of pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH), which is caused by an inactivating mutation in the BMPR2 gene. Elevated pulmonary arterial pressure is a hallmark of PAH. Chronic intravascular hemolysis and fibrosis of the pulmonary parenchyma are not associated with this condition. Thickening of the interventricular septum is seen in hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, which is not related to the patient’s symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, family history, and genetic analysis suggest pulmonary hypertension caused by an inactivating mutation in the BMPR2 gene. Elevated pulmonary arterial pressure is characteristic of pulmonary hypertension, while options A, B, and C are not typically associated with this condition.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and a family history of similar symptoms indicate that the most likely cause is pulmonary arterial hypertension. The inactivating mutation in the BMPR2 gene is commonly associated with this condition. The normal diffusion capacity rules out fibrosis of the pulmonary parenchyma, and thickening of the interventricular septum is not usually associated with pulmonary hypertension. Chronic intravascular hemolysis is associated with other conditions such as sickle cell disease but is not commonly associated with pulmonary hypertension.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has a family history of respiratory failure and genetic analysis shows an inactivating mutation in the BMPR2 gene, which is associated with pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH). The symptoms of shortness of breath and fatigue are also commonly seen in PAH. Pulmonary function testing shows normal diffusion capacity, ruling out fibrosis of the pulmonary parenchyma. Chronic intravascular hemolysis and thickening of the interventricular septum are not associated with BMPR2 mutations or PAH. The ECG findings are non-specific.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest pulmonary hypertension, which is confirmed by the genetic analysis that shows an inactivating mutation in BMPR2 gene. Elevated pulmonary arterial pressure is a key feature of pulmonary hypertension, while the other options are not typically associated with this condition.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms, family history, and genetic analysis suggest pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH), which is associated with BMPR2 gene mutations. Pulmonary function testing shows a normal diffusion capacity, ruling out fibrosis of the pulmonary parenchyma. Chronic intravascular hemolysis and thickening of the interventricular septum are not associated with these symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The finding of an inactivating mutation in the BMPR2 gene suggests a diagnosis of pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH). The shortness of breath and fatigue are typical symptoms of PAH, and the clear lungs and normal diffusion capacity suggest that the problem is not in the lungs themselves, but in the pulmonary vasculature. The elevated QRS axis is a nonspecific finding, but it can be seen in patients with PAH due to right ventricular hypertrophy. Chronic intravascular hemolysis, fibrosis of the pulmonary parenchyma, and thickening of the interventricular septum are not typically associated with PAH.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms suggest pulmonary hypertension. The inactivating mutation in the BMPR2 gene is a known cause of hereditary pulmonary arterial hypertension. The lung function testing with normal diffusion capacity suggests the pulmonary arterial pressure is elevated rather than fibrosis or thickening of the interventricular septum. Chronic intravascular hemolysis is seen in sickle cell anemia, but not related to the patient's symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms, as well as the genetic analysis result, suggest pulmonary hypertension. Elevated pulmonary arterial pressure is the most likely cause of the patient’s symptoms. Chronic intravascular hemolysis is seen in diseases such as sickle cell anemia, and fibrosis of the pulmonary parenchyma is seen in diseases such as idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis. Thickening of the interventricular septum is seen in hypertrophic cardiomyopathy.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms, family history, and genetic analysis suggest pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH) caused by an inactivating mutation in the BMPR2 gene. The normal diffusion capacity and clear lungs suggest that fibrosis of the pulmonary parenchyma is less likely to be the cause. Chronic intravascular hemolysis and thickening of the interventricular septum are not associated with PAH.
